questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress; RR=70/minute; air entry reduced in midaxilla; grunting audible with stethoscope; cyanosis on room air; mild retractions. What is his Downe’s score?
What is the most important component of surfactant?
At what stage of lung development, is surfactant seen in the type II pneumocytes?
A 29 week, 600gm baby is born in the labour room. The baby has moderate respiratory distress, with a silverman score 6. What is the next appropriate step?
Below shown is an X Ray of a preterm, 600gms who presented with abdominal distension. Which stage of Bell’s staging is this?
Which statement about NEC is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Meta-analysis of 6 RCTs comparing formula feeds versus human milk in preterm infants showed that preterm infants fed with formula have equal incidence of NEC

options.label: B
options.text: Incidence of NEC is significantly reduced after antenatal steroids given to pregnant women with preterm labor or premature rupture of membranes

options.label: C
options.text: Minimal enteral nutrition and standard feeding guidelines have proven benefit in decreasing the incidence of NEC.

options.label: D
options.text: Probiotics: Meta-analysis of 30 RCTs and 14 observational studies show a significant reduction in severe (stage II or more) NEC with a relative risk of 0.57

questions.correct_answer: A. Meta-analysis of 6 RCTs comparing formula feeds versus human milk in preterm infants showed that preterm infants fed with formula have equal incidence of NEC

questions.text: According to MOHFW 2016 guidelines, when should a screening for ROP be done in babies < 1200gms?
Retinal angiogenesis normally proceeds from the optic disc to the periphery, reaching the outer rim of the retina. When does it start?
A 42 week, 1600gms newborn is born with meconium stained liquor. He is limp and apneic after the initial steps. What is the next step?
Which limb is taken as preductal as a convention in neonatal resuscitation?
What is 3 minute target for spO2% in newborns?

You are called to a crash Cesarean-section. After the birth you are concerned about the baby’s condition and assess heart rate: According to resuscitation guidelines, at which point should you commence chest compressions?
questions.correct_answer: B. Less than 60 beats per minute

questions.text: A term baby is born by emergency Caesarean section following a prolonged fetal bradycardia. The baby mad o respiratory effort and has been intubated. Baby is receiving uninterrupted breaths and chest compressions. A saturation probe placed on the baby’s right hand shows undetectable oxygen saturations and displays a heart rate only when chest compressions are ongoing. An emergency umbilical venous catheter (UVC) has been placed and heart rate remains undetectable whenever compressions are stopped. Chest compressions and breaths are currently ongoing. Baby is now 8 min old and the consultant is on their way from home. What is the next most appropriate step?

options.label: C
options.text: Suction with wide-bore catheter under direct vision

options.label: D
options.text: Turn down temperature to begin cooling the baby

questions.text: If a newborn is started on chest compressions in addition to PPV, which is of the following measure is not required?

An infant is being investigated for persistent jaundice and has a systolic murmur consistent with pulmonary valve disease. Ophthalmological assessment reveals an anterior-segment abnormality. What is the most likely skeletal manifestation?

A Pakistani couple are referred for genetic counseling. They lost two children who both died in the first 2 years of life. They have one healthy girl, who is 3 years of age. The faulty gene has been identified and other members of their family have been tested. What is the pattern of inheritance in this disorder?

You are working in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) and assess a new admission. A term baby girl born via normal delivery required intubation and ventilation in view of poor respiratory effort. The cord gases were normal, as was her admission capillary blood gas. On examination you notice bilateral talipes but no other abnormalities. The baby has not moved and has marked hypotonia, despite the absence of sedation. You take the family history and no other babies have been born with similar problems. The mother mentions that she has been recently diagnosed with cataracts, as have a number of her relatives. Her brother has recently been admitted to hospital for a pacemaker insertion aged 30 years. Which investigation is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?

A couple, MR and Mrs Brown, come to see you. Mrs Brown is pregnant. Mrs Brown had a brother and a maternal uncle who both had Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). The couple have just had a scan which showed that the baby is male. What is the chance that the baby shall also have DMD?
This boy has proximal muscle weakness, aged 6 years. What is your diagnosis?
This MRI image is taken from a bed ridden 7 years old boy. What is your diagnosis?
What is the treatment of choice for the boy in previous question?
What is the inheritance of Dent disease and Lowe syndrome?
What is the inheritance in the below shown image?
What is the inheritance of Coffin lowry and Aicardi syndromes?

You review an 8-years-old boy who attends a school for moderate learning difficulties. His neonatal history includes intrauterine growth retardation, neonatal history includes intrauterine growth retardation, neonatal hypotonia and hypoglycaemia. He was a difficult feeder and required nasogastric feeds. As an infant, he became obese. On entry to nursery school, he was referred for eating soil, paper and other objects. On examination, the boy has short stature, mild dysmorphism with almond-shaped eyes and a downturned fish-mouth appearance. He has small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. He has speech and language delay with poor development progression. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Disorder of maternal uniparental disomy

questions.text: What is the inheritance of Pallister killian syndrome and hypomelanosis of ito?
What is the inheritance of deafness, due to aminoglycosides?

You are asked to investigate a 5-years-old boy who has autistic features. His OFC is on the 89th centile, but height and weight are on the 50th centile. He also has large ears. Karyotype was normal. His mother suffered a premature menopause aged 36. What is the most likely diagnosis?
The fragile site in Fragile X syndrome is at which locus?

An 11-months-old child is given a breakfast cereal containing cashew nuts. He suddenly has stridor and is struggling to breathe. There is no rash or wheeze and he remains conscious. He is brought to your resuscitation unit tired and unable to cough.

A 1-month old infant is brought to the Emergency Department. The triage nurse brings the patient back immediately stating that the patient is ill appearing, tachycardic to 188, and hypotensive with BP-50/35. The patient’s skin is mottled and the capillary refill is 6 seconds with weakly palpable pulses in all 4 extremities. The patient’s abdomen is distended and the liver edge is palpable well below the costal margin. You obtain blood and urine studies, a chest radiograph, and begin a 20 mL/kg intravenous fluid bolus. Reassessment following the bolus reveals that the patient has developed rales and is now arousable only to stimulus. The next step in the management of this patient would be:
What is the inotrope of choice in warm, pediatric septic shock?
According to 2020 Surviving sepsis guidelines in children, which statement is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Recommend starting antimicrobial therapy as soon as possible, within 1 h of recognition

options.label: B
options.text: In healthcare systems with availability of intensive care, we suggest administering up to 40–60 mL/kg in bolus fluid (10–20 mL/kg per bolus) over the first hour, titrated to clinical markers of cardiac output and discontinued if signs of fluid overload develop

options.label: C
options.text: Suggest using epinephrine, rather than dopamine, in children with septic shock

options.label: D
options.text: Suggest not to use either intravenous hydrocortisone or no hydrocortisone may be used if adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor therapy are not able to restore hemodynamic stability

questions.correct_answer: D. Suggest not to use either intravenous hydrocortisone or no hydrocortisone may be used if adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor therapy are not able to restore hemodynamic stability

questions.text: A 2 yr old child child is given a breakfast cereal containing cashew nuts. He suddenly has stridor and is struggling to breathe. There is no rash or wheeze and he remains conscious. He is brought to your resuscitation unit tired and unable to cough.
When does a child have a vocabulary of 50-100 words?
When does a child have a vocabulary of more than 2000 words?
When can a child make a tower of 7 cubes and put three words together ie subject, verb, object?
When can a child throw ball overhand, uses scissors to cut a picture and tell a story?
When can a child name 4 colors and name heavier of 2 weights?
Which short stature is depicted by the third curve from below?
Which short stature is depicted by second curve from below?
In which short stature, bone age approximately the chronological age?
A 2 yr old child has acute diarrhea since 4 days. He is thirsty, turgor goes back slowly and is playful. What should be the next plan as per WHO?
What is the total osmolarity in the Low osmolarity ORS?
What is the amount of trisodium citrate in gms in low osmolarity ORS?
What is the dose of zinc in a 3 months old child with diarrhea?
Which statement is not true about this 6 months old child with skin lesions?

options.label: B
options.text: Dose of zinc is 3mg/kg for 2 yrs

questions.correct_answer: B. Dose of zinc is 3mg/kg for 2 yrs

questions.text: What is the recommended maintainence fluid in children?
What is the composition of potassium in Ringer lactate in meq/L?
Which of the following has highest arterial pO2 during fetal life?
At what arterial pO2 in mmHg, ductus arteriosus closes?
You are evaluating a newborn in the nursery for hypotonia, dysmorphic features, and a heart murmur. Based on these features, what is the most likely chromosome abnormality and heart defect?
questions.correct_answer: B. Trisomy 21: complete atrioventricular canal defect

questions.text: This is an ECG of a 10 weeks old baby with failure to thrive, pneumonia and excessive sweating. What does this ECG show and what is the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: This EKG is consistent with sinus bradycardia. Begin workup for sepsis and start antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: This EKG is consistent with a superior axis. Obtain echocardiogram to evaluate for endocardial cushion defect

options.label: C
options.text: This EKG is consistent with complete heart block. Send mother’s blood for autoantibodies anti SSA-Ro and SSB-La to evaluate for neonatal lupus erythematosus and obtain an echocardiogram on the baby to evaluate for myocardial depression

options.label: D
options.text: LVH and Look for VSD in the child

questions.correct_answer: B. This EKG is consistent with a superior axis. Obtain echocardiogram to evaluate for endocardial cushion defect

questions.text: Below is shown an echocardiogram of a cyanotic newborn. What would you suspect in the baby?

You are caring for a 2.2-kg term infant with cleft palate and a small chin. A fetal echocardiogram diagnosed truncus arteriosus, which was confirmed postnatally. There is a small or absent thymus on the echocardiogram. What is most likely underlying genetic abnormality?

Your gastroenterology colleagues request your help to evaluate a murmur in a 3-year-old with a history of jaundice and cholestasis. You note that he has a history of mild developmental delay and has unusual facial features (broad forehead, deep-set eyes, pointed chin). The chest X-ray shows a normal cardiac silhouette, but butterfly-shaped vertebrae. You hear normal S1 and S2, no valve clicks, and peripheral PS murmurs bilaterally. What gene defect should you test for?

options.label: B
options.text: PTPN11 mutation in the RAS/MAP pathway

questions.text: A previously normal newborn infant in a community hospital nursery is noted to be cyanotic at 14 hours of life. She is placed on a face mask with oxygen flowing at 10 L/min. She remains cyanotic, and her pulse oximetry reading does not change. An arterial blood gas shows her Pa02 to be 23 mm Hg. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and she has no murmur. She is breathing deeply and quickly, but she is not retracting. While you are waiting for the transport team from the nearby children's hospital, you should initiate which of the following?

A 4-day-old infant presents with decreased oral intake and decreased activity. Birth history was unremarkable and he was discharged home on day 2 of his life. Physical exam reveals a cool, mottled infant, with decreased pulses. No significant murmur is audible. Which is the most likely congenital heart defect?

You are seeing a newborn boy 10 days old. The birth was uncomplicated and he was discharged from the well-baby nursery at age 2 days. His mother notes that over the past day he has had “heavy breathing” and has a hard time breast-feeding. His vital signs are as follows: heart rate is 170, respiratory rate is 65 and labored, and it is difficult to obtain blood pressure in the leg. On exam there is a strong pulse in the right brachial, but very weak pulses at both femoral arteries. On pulse oximetry, saturation in the right hand is 99% and in the left foot is 82%.

options.label: B
options.text: Left ventricular dysfunction due to cardiomyopathy

questions.correct_answer: A. Critical coarctation of the aorta

questions.text: Which of the following lesion is not ductal dependent?
A 6 weeks old baby presents with failure to thrive and feeding diaphoresis. His X Ray is shown below. This anamoly subtype represents what % of TAPVC cases?

You are evaluating a 3-month-old boy in your office who you know to have tetralogy of Fallot. His mother informs you that the infant has had fever, diarrhea, and poor feeding in the last 24 hours. On physical examination, you note cyanosis of the extremities and perioral area, tachypnea, hyperpnea, and a heart rate of 180 beats per min. At the last visit you recall a harsh 3/6 systolic ejection murmur; today you do not hear a murmur. Of the following, the MOST appropriate management strategy is to:

options.label: B
options.text: Reassure his mother because the murmur is gone

options.label: C
options.text: Order echocardiogram to evaluate the pulmonary valve

options.label: D
options.text: Place him in the knee–chest position with oxygen

questions.correct_answer: D. Place him in the knee–chest position with oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following agent shall not be used in the previous child?
What does the figure below shows which shunt?
The below shown shape on a Chest X Ray is due to which chamber hypertrophy?
The below shown rash is seen in which phase of Kawasaki disease?
A 4 yrs old boy presents with fever since 5 days, generalized rash, red tongue, unilateral cervical lymph node and unexplained tachycardia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

You have recently seen a 5-year-old boy with fever for 5 days, has a bright red tongue, cracked red lips, conjunctivitis, a large cervical lymph node, and a diffuse erythematous rash. His ESR is 120. What would you do next to treat this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a blood culture and start broad-spectrum antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Admit tonight for intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin. Order an echocardiogram for tomorrow

options.label: C
options.text: Discharge from the ER with follow-up if fever persists another 48 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe amoxicillin and follow up in primary care clinic tomorrow

questions.correct_answer: B. Admit tonight for intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin. Order an echocardiogram for tomorrow

questions.text: Which drug is not used in resistant cases of Kawasaki disease?

A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with complaints of ankle pain and rash. He is noted on exam to have bilateral ankle swelling, which is periarticular and nonpitting in nature. He has a purpuric rash on his bilateral lower extremities, scrotum; and buttocks; it is nonblanching and nonmigratory. His platelet count and hemoglobin are normal and his WBC count is elevated to 15,000/mm3. PT and aPTT are normal. Urinalysis is negative. What anticipatory guidance do you provide the family?

options.label: A
options.text: His ankle swelling should be treated with NSAIDs and will become chronic

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of nephritis will be present for the next several years and he should be screened regular during that time

options.label: C
options.text: The onset of abdominal pain is most likely from his NSAID and should be treated symptomatically.

options.label: D
options.text: The rash may come and go for weeks to months following the initial presentation

questions.correct_answer: D. The rash may come and go for weeks to months following the initial presentation

questions.text: The above child is at risk of nephritis within how many weeks of onset of disease?
If the above child shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria, the kidney biopsy shall show proliferation of

A 7-years-old boy presents with a 10-days history of purpura on his arms and legs. He has had 3 days of pain and swelling of his ankles and left knee but is ambulant. On examination he is apyrexial, his capillary refill is 1 second, pulse 100 beats per minute, blood pressure 105/80 mmHg. Urine dipstick shows blood + + and protein + + +. Bloods on admission revealed haemoglobin 132 g/L, white count 6.7 x 109L, platelets 273 x 109/L, sodium 140 mmol/L, potassium 3.7 mmol/L, urea 3.0 mmol/L, creatinine 42 μmol/L and C reactive protein < 2. Which of the following actions would be the BEST?
According to American Heart Association, 2015 Jones criteria, new Major criteria included for moderate to high risk populations is
According to American Heart Association, 2015 Jones criteria, new Major criteria included for moderate to high risk populations is
What is the most common cause of pneumonia in newborns all over the world?
What is the most common bacterial cause of pneumonia in children from 3 weeks of life to 3 yrs of life in India and the World?

A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with fever to 102.5Åã F, sore throat, irritability, and refusal to eat or drink. Symptoms began that morning and have progressed over the past few hours. You note the child to be ill appearing, leaning forward, and drooling. There are no ill contacts and the child has received all immunizations. You keep the child comfortable with his mother and immediately contact anesthesia and otolaryngology to assist with further management. If neck films were ordered, the most likely finding would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Irregularity of the tracheal air column

questions.text: What is the most common cause of Epiglottitis all over the world?

A 2 yrs old boy presents to you with fever, barky cough and cold. Since last 2 days, he has developed inspiratory sound at rest, and he is not able to drink water. He appears blue. Which of the following should be next step?
Recurrent Pneumonia is defined as

options.label: A
options.text: 2 or more episodes in 1 yr or 3 episodes ever

options.label: B
options.text: 3 or more episodes in 1 yr or 4 episodes ever

questions.correct_answer: A. 2 or more episodes in 1 yr or 3 episodes ever

questions.text: A previously healthy 2 yr old girl is given oral antibiotic therapy for a cough, fever, and patchy consolidation of the right lower lobe. No crackles are heard on chest auscultation. The fever abates, the cough improves, but a follow-up chest radiograph at 8 wk demonstrates persistent consolidation involving the right lower lobe. Next steps in the evaluation should include:

A 5 yr old boy with AIDS and who is receiving zidovudine, lamivudine, and ritonavir presents with rapid respiratory rate and progressive dyspnea of 2 days' duration. There is no fever. The chest radiograph reveals bilateral diffuse alveolar disease. The most important diagnostic test would be:

options.label: B
options.text: Pharyngeal swab for viral and bacterial cultures

questions.correct_answer: D. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) for cytology & PCR

questions.text: A 7 yr old child with a 3-yr history of cough, intermittent wheezing, and poor growth has 2 sweat chloride values of 36 and 41 mEq/L. Additional diagnostic testing to rule out cystic fibrosis should include:

options.label: D
options.text: DNA analysis for the DeltaF508 mutation

questions.text: DeltaF508 mutation has a functional defect on the CFTR channel. It leads to

options.label: B
options.text: Defect in protein trafficking with ubiquitination and degradation in endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi body

options.label: C
options.text: Defective regulation; CFTR not activated by adenosine triphosphate or cyclic adenosine monophosphate

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced chloride transport through CFTR at the apical membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Defect in protein trafficking with ubiquitination and degradation in endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi body

questions.text: Which drug is made for G551D CFTR mutation?
G551D is which class of CFTR mutation?
Following statement is true about the Cystic fibrosis airways

options.label: A
options.text: The membranes of CF epithelial cells are unable to secrete chloride ions in response to cyclic adenosine monophosphate–mediated signals, and at least in the respiratory tract, excessive amounts of sodium are absorbed through these membranes

options.label: B
options.text: The membranes of CF epithelial cells are unable to secrete sodium ions in response to cyclic adenosine monophosphate– mediated signals, and at least in the respiratory tract, excessive amounts of chloride are absorbed through these membranes

options.label: C
options.text: The membranes of CF epithelial cells are unable to secrete sodium ions in response to cyclic adenosine monophosphate– mediated signals, and at least in the respiratory tract, excessive amounts of sodium are absorbed through these membranes

options.label: D
options.text: None of the following is true

questions.correct_answer: A. The membranes of CF epithelial cells are unable to secrete chloride ions in response to cyclic adenosine monophosphate–mediated signals, and at least in the respiratory tract, excessive amounts of sodium are absorbed through these membranes

questions.text: The latest FDA approval for therapy for DeltaF508 patients includes all except
The most common cause of pneumonia in children with cystic fibrosis is
What is the risk of recurrence if a child has no risk factors in case of febrile seizures?

Anne, a 6-years-old girl, is seen by her general practitioner. Her mother and school teacher have noticed she has episodes where she stops her activity for a few seconds, stares blankly ahead and then resumes the activity as if she had never stopped. These episodes happen many times a day. She has no other medical problems and there is no family history of note. The EEG during an episode is shown Choose the most likely diagnosis.

Vijay is a 5-months-old infant who has been seen repeatedly by his general practitioner because of colic. His mother brings him to the Accident and Emergency department as he is having episodes of suddenly throwing his head and arms forward. These episodes occur in repetitive bursts. His mother thinks they may be something more than just colic, as he is now not smiling or supporting his head as well as he did previously. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and has no other medical problems.

options.label: B
options.text: Childhood Rolandic epilepsy (benign epilepsy with centro-temporal spikes)

questions.text: A 15 yr old girl presents with frequent jerks more in the awakening. Her sister also died of similar complaints. Her EEG on photic stimulation is shown below. Which drug should not be used in her?
If valproate is to be avoided in previous case, what would be the next drug to be used?
Which organism is the most common cause of meningitis in CSF leaks and cochlear implants?
What should be the drug of choice for meningitis in children?
A 2 yrs old child is brought with fever and coma since 5 days. His T2W MRI brain image is shown. What should be the next step?

Finlay, a 5-years-old boy, recently had a birthday party at his local farm. Since then he has had 3 days of diarrhoea. The loose stool had some blood in it. His mother is concerned as he is still not himself. He appears to be very pale and has not passed urine for 12 hours. He has no other medical problems and is not normally on any medication. On examination you note that he has pale conjunctivae. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. You decide to take some blood tests and get the following results: • haemoglobin: 76 g/L; white blood cells: 14.2 x 109/L; platelet count: 50 x 109/L • creatinine: 200 μmol/L (normal: 20-80 μmol/L) • prothrombin time: 13 seconds (control: 12-15 s) • activated partial thromboplastin time: 34 seconds (control: 25-35 s) What is the most likely diagnosis? Select one answer only.
What is the most common of the disease in previous question in India?
